page.title: 02ECOLOGY-HAMSTERLEY FOREST
page.content: The geology of the area and the management of the land are the major influences on the flora and fauna.It is only in the valley bottoms and streamsides that vegetation is able to reach a normal type,with alder dominating the river banks. The soils are acid and shallow overlying sandstone with varied sand and gravel glacial deposits.The area therefore is a patchwork of small pockets of soil,though all are of poor potential.The normal climax vegetation would be silver birch and pine trees or sessile oak with an undergrowth of heather,bracken and bilberry. Forestry is an obvious use of land which is very exposed,especially the steep-sided valleys.The potential for any form of high productivety farming is poor as the soil is suitable only for low grazing.
